trial_identification.studytitle: The effects of moderate exercise on breath levels of pentane
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In healthy participants, can moderate exercise reliably increase breath pentane levels compared with other markers of oxidative stress?

conditions.healthcondition: oxidative stress responses to moderate exercise

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal metabolism and endocrine development and function

interventions.interventions: Participants will perform four sessions of moderate exercise on a rowing ergometer, with one week between each session. In the first session, blood will be sampled from the earlobe during exercise to determine the exercise intensity corresponding to the lactate threshold. This session will last long enough to determine the lactate threshold, no longer than 30 minutes in total. In sessions two through four, participants will exercise for 30 minutes, with breath and blood samples collected pre-exercise, immediately post-exercise, and at 0.5, 1, 2, and 6 hours post-exercise.
interventions.comparator: Each participant's breath and blood samples will be compared between their pre-exercise and post-exercise time points.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Changes in breath levels of pentane in response to exercise as measured by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Immediately before and after exercise, and 0.5, 1, 2, and 6 hours later

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Changes in blood levels of malondialdehyde and protein carbonyls (markers of oxidative stress) in response to exercise
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Immediately before and after exercise, and 0.5, 1, 2, and 6 hours later

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Healthy participants who do not perform regular aerobic exercise
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Any conditions likely to affect the participant's ability to perform moderate exercise

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: The Horticulture and Food Research Institute of New Zealand Ltd. (HortResearch)

fundingsource.fundingname: Foundation for Research, Science and Technology (FRST)
